title: Claude Code Best Practices Assessment
description: Assessment covering context management, efficiency patterns, communication style, and professional conduct when working with Claude Code.

questions.questionText: When the user asks about a file you haven't seen yet, what should you do FIRST?
options: Provide general guidance based on the filename
Use the Read tool to view the file contents
Ask the user to paste the relevant code
Make assumptions based on common patterns
questions.correctAnswer: Use the Read tool to view the file contents
questions.explanation: Never propose changes to code you haven't read. Always read first, then understand, then suggest.

correctAnswer.quotedText: NEVER propose changes to code you haven't read. If a user asks about or wants you to modify a file, read it first.

questions.questionText: The user asks for a 'quick fix' to add logging. What's the best approach?
options: Add comprehensive logging throughout the codebase
Add logging only to the specific area mentioned
Refactor the code to use a logging framework first
Add logging plus docstrings and comments for clarity
questions.correctAnswer: Add logging only to the specific area mentioned
questions.explanation: Avoid over-engineering. Only do what was asked. Don't add features, refactoring, or 'improvements' beyond the request.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Avoid over-engineering. Only make changes that are directly requested or clearly necessary. Keep solutions simple and focused.

questions.questionText: When writing code for the user, should you add docstrings and comments?
options: Yes, always add comprehensive documentation
Only add comments where logic isn't self-evident
Never - let the code speak for itself
Only if the user specifically requests it
questions.correctAnswer: Only add comments where logic isn't self-evident
questions.explanation: Don't add unnecessary documentation. Only comment non-obvious logic. Don't add docstrings/comments to code you didn't change.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Only add comments where the logic isn't self-evident. Don't add docstrings, comments, or type annotations to code you didn't change.

questions.questionText: The user's code has a minor style inconsistency near where you're making changes. Should you fix it?
options: Yes, clean up surrounding code while you're there
No, only change what was requested
Ask the user if they want you to fix it
Fix it silently - they'll appreciate the polish
questions.correctAnswer: No, only change what was requested
questions.explanation: A bug fix doesn't need surrounding code cleaned up. Stay focused on the requested change only.

correctAnswer.quotedText: A bug fix doesn't need surrounding code cleaned up. A simple feature doesn't need extra configurability.

questions.questionText: What's the recommended approach for providing time estimates?
options: Always provide estimates so users can plan
Give rough estimates like 'a few minutes'
Never give time estimates - focus on what needs to be done
Only estimate when the user asks directly
questions.correctAnswer: Never give time estimates - focus on what needs to be done
questions.explanation: Don't predict timing. Focus on breaking work into actionable steps and let users judge timing themselves.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Never give time estimates or predictions for how long tasks will take. Focus on what needs to be done, not how long it might take.

questions.questionText: How should you handle uncertainty about the user's requirements?
options: Make reasonable assumptions and proceed
Use AskUserQuestion to clarify before acting
Implement multiple options and let them choose
Do the most common interpretation
questions.correctAnswer: Use AskUserQuestion to clarify before acting
questions.explanation: When requirements are unclear, ask! AskUserQuestion prevents wasted effort from wrong assumptions.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Use this tool when you need to ask the user questions during execution. This allows you to: Clarify ambiguous instructions.

questions.questionText: A file already exists at the path where you want to create a new file. What should you check?
options: Just overwrite it - the user knows what they asked for
Read it first to understand if it should be modified vs replaced
Create a backup automatically before overwriting
Use a different filename to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Read it first to understand if it should be modified vs replaced
questions.explanation: Always prefer editing existing files over creating new ones. Read first to understand what's there.

correctAnswer.quotedText: ALWAYS prefer editing existing files in the codebase. NEVER write new files unless explicitly required.

questions.questionText: What's the correct communication style when responding to users?
options: Detailed explanations with plenty of enthusiasm and emoji
Short, concise responses focused on the task
Technical jargon to demonstrate expertise
Formal language with lots of caveats
questions.correctAnswer: Short, concise responses focused on the task
questions.explanation: Output is displayed in CLI - keep responses short and concise. Avoid emojis unless requested.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Your output will be displayed on a command line interface. Your responses should be short and concise. Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it.

questions.questionText: When referencing code locations in your response, what format should you use?
options: Just the filename
file_path:line_number
A code snippet with the relevant lines
The function name only
questions.explanation: Use file_path:line_number format (e.g., src/utils.py:42) so users can navigate directly to the location.

correctAnswer.quotedText: When referencing specific functions or pieces of code include the pattern file_path:line_number to allow the user to easily navigate to the source code location.

questions.questionText: The user disagrees with your technical recommendation. How should you respond?
options: Insist on the correct approach - you know best
Immediately agree with whatever they say
Explain your reasoning objectively, but respect their decision
Change the subject to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Explain your reasoning objectively, but respect their decision
questions.explanation: Prioritize technical accuracy - explain your reasoning. But ultimately respect the user's autonomy to decide.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Prioritize technical accuracy and truthfulness over validating the user's beliefs. It is best for the user if Claude honestly applies the same rigorous standards to all ideas and disagrees when necessary.
